bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, February 27, 1950

div1.p: Siler discusses suggestions to change the inscription on a plaque memorializing Reed's place of death. He discusses a resolution introduced in Congress to honor the memory of Reed. Siler informs Hench of Osborne Wood's death.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, February 27, 1950
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
-----
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6. D. C.
February 27, 1950.
JOSEPH F. SILER
PRESIDENT
MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL
WALTER A. BLOEDORN
SECRETARY
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p: Thank you so much for your letter of February 16th.

I took up with a number of the members of the Board of the Walter
Reed Memorial Association the matter of making a change in the inscription
to be placed on the plaque, and after talking with four or five who live
here in Washington, it was felt that your suggestion:
WALTER REED
the conqueror of yellow fever
died in a hospital
on this site
November 23- 1902
would be very satisfactory. When I called up Doctor Soper concerning the
question of making the change, he felt that it would not be quite right to
use the term “conqueror of yellow fever.” I am enclosing herewith a copy
of his letter for your information.

After receiving Doctor Soper's letter, I consulted General Kean
concerning the whole matter, and we both feel that your suggestion -
“the conqueror of yellow fever” is quite satisfactory, but if any change
should be considered, it might be well to give consideration to the follow-
ing change, which will incorporate, in substance, the statement made by
President Eliot, of Harvard, many years ago:
WALTER REED
who gave man control over yellow fever
died in a hospital
on this site
November 23- 1902

This morning I consulted the Lamb Seal & Stencil Co., who will
make the sign for us, concerning the feasibility of making these two changes.
They are preparing a new sketch, showing the size of the lettering which
would have to be used in each of the two types of wording, and when we have
received that, we will come to a final decision. I may say, for your in-
formation, that I think your suggestion - “the conqueror of yellow fever”
is quite all right. As soon as we come to some definite decision I will,
Dr. Hench
page 2
of course, advise you concerning the matter.

I presume that you have received a letter from a Mr. Wallach, en-
closing copies of the Resolutions introduced in Congress to honor the
memory of Walter Reed. Personally, I feel that the sum of $350,000 over
a period of 3 years could be spent much more advantageously in honoring
Walter Reed's memory than through educational publicity, as suggested in
the Resolutions. I, of course, feel as you do - that something should be
done to bring to the attention of the people of this country the accomplish-
ments of Walter Reed during this, the 50th Anniversary Year of his work,
and I had understood that it was your intention to get some outstanding
writers to cover the matter in articles in journals.

Thank you so much for offering to send the reprints. I am sure
that the Surgeon General will be delighted to get them for distribution
to members of the Corps.

I wonder if you have heard of the death, recently, of Osborne
Wood. It was my feeling that you would be interested in this because of
your recent contacts with his sister, Miss Wood.

Please do not bother to answer this letter, as I know you are
very, very busy, and we all fell that you must take the very best care
of yourself.
